citation.article-title: Pseudogulbenkiania subflava gen. nov., sp. nov., isolated from a cold spring.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Pseudogulbenkiania (Pseu.do.gul.ben′ki.a.ni.a. Gr. adj. pseudes false; N.L. fem. n. Gulbenkiania a bacterial generic name; N.L. fem. n. Pseudogulbenkiania false Gulbenkiania).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming rods occurring either singly or in pairs.
Cells are aerobic, motile by means of a single polar flagellum, oxidase-positive and catalase-negative.
Chemo-organotrophic and able to utilize a large spectrum of carbon sources.
The predominant fatty acids are summed feature 3 (C16 : 1ω7c and/or iso-C15 : 0 2-OH), C16 : 0 and C18 : 1ω7c.
The major polar lipids are diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylethanolamine.
The major respiratory quinone is ubiquinone Q-8.
The type species is Pseudogulbenkiania subflava.
